metadata.titel_preek: Seeing Our Hurts With God's Eyes

primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God (the Husbandman) prunes the believer (the branch) through suffering and hurt to produce greater spiritual fruit and conformity to Christ.

tekstueel_bewijs: the Lord of the vineyard, purges, cuts the branch end
the Lord works on us that way
God is bringing to pass something in you and me
that it may bring forth more fruit
make us conformable to his death
there is no room in the economy of the kingdom for purposelessness

ontvanger.identificatie: The Believer / The World (through the fruit)
tekstueel_bewijs: He's growing us into his likeness
More of his grace to others show

helper.identificatie: Sorrow/Trouble (as instruments) and Jesus (as the Vine/Pattern)

tegenstander.identificatie: Fruitlessness, Top-heaviness, and the 'Chill' of the world
tekstueel_bewijs: every branch in me that beareth not fruit he taketh away
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not just bad luck, but a state of spiritual purposelessness that leads to being 'cut off' from the source of life.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The believer's response to the pruning: yielding to the process.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Hearer
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The believer's 'yielding' is the necessary response to God's active 'pruning'.

voorbeelden_god_subject: the Lord of the vineyard, purges
God is bringing to pass something
the Lord makes his rain to fall
voorbeelden_mens_subject: we suffer probably because of our makeup

voorbeelden: the way we ought to look upon them
Do you long for that, more?
seeing our hurts with God's eyes
how a Christian views the things

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon emphasizes God's power (Pouvoir) to transform suffering into fruit, rather than the human obligation (Devoir) to fix oneself.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: The sermon moves from the 'not-S2' (the pain of pruning) to 'S1' (fruitfulness), arguing that S1 is impossible without the negation of S2 through God's active cutting.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension is resolved by redefining 'hurt' not as an end, but as a divine tool for 'making' the person.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High; the threat of being 'cut off' and 'taken away' is presented as the ultimate consequence of fruitlessness.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: While the sermon deals with human suffering, God remains the primary actor (Subject). Suffering is not something humans must 'overcome' by will, but something God 'uses' by His power.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: the difference with which the righteous and the unrighteous receive the rain

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: the Lord is not out to make us comfortable, but to make us conformable

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Stephen is used as an example, but the focus is on what Stephen *saw* (Christ standing) rather than Stephen's own strength.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already leans theocentric by showing Christ as the one standing for Stephen.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Consolation and surrender; shifting from 'why is this happening to me' to 'what is God doing'.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Sanctification is a monergistic work of God where the human is the 'clay'.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The metaphor of the vine and husbandman is consistently applied to the problem of human suffering.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'punished by our sins' and 'pruned for fruitfulness' is left slightly unresolved.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: conformable to his death and to his suffering... raised in the likeness of his resurrection

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The sermon attributes the 'Pouvoir' directly to the Father/Husbandman.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Moderate; sin is seen as fruitlessness or 'top-heaviness' that requires divine surgery.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully maintains God as the Subject of the sanctification process. The hearer is positioned as the 'branch' or 'clay', which is biblically consistent with the text.

identificatie_herstel.problematische_identificatie: The farmer example (righteous vs unrighteous) momentarily shifts the hearer into a Subject role of 'choosing' how to view rain.
identificatie_herstel.strategie: Emphasize that the 'righteous heart' that thanks God is also a gift from the Husbandman.

modale_balans.huidige_onbalans: Heavy on Savoir (knowing how to see) and Pouvoir (God's power).
modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Increase Vouloir (the Spirit's work in the heart to desire the pruning).
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Connect the 'yielding' not to human willpower but to the Spirit's internal work.

tegenstander_intensivering.huidige_status: The opponent (suffering/death) is treated with significant weight.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: The hierarchy of God acting and man yielding is well-maintained.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This is a masterful grace-oriented sermon that avoids the trap of 'five steps to handle grief' by keeping the Husbandman's knife as the primary instrument of hope.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: A rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'mountain' metaphor; Greimas shows that the 'mountain' is actually the Opponent that the Subject (God) is navigating.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis would focus on the Greek of 'kathairei'; semiotics shows how this verb functions as the 'Performance' of the Divine Subject.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas reveals that the sermon's power comes from the 'Subject-switch'—moving the hearer from a 'trapped' Subject to a 'pruned' Object in God's hands.

volledige_subject_lijst: God (prunes, cuts, makes, grows, brings to pass)
We (attach importance, suffer, have done wrong, wait, yield)
volledige_object_lijst: The fullness of the stature of Christ
appendices.notities: The sermon uses 'passive' suffering as the location for 'active' divine grace.
